parameters.source_text:
The case of Mr R
Mr R was born with a serious malformation of the brain and cerebral palsy. At eight months of age he developed severe epilepsy. At the age of 23 he had spastic diplegia (paralysis) and was incontinent, as well as apparently deaf and blind (with possible vestigial response to a buzzer and to light). He was unable to walk, to sit upright or to chew; so that food had to be syringed to the back of his mouth. His bowels had to be evacuated manually because his limited diet resulted in serious constipation. He suffered from thrush and had ulcers all the way through his guts, according to testimony. When cuddled he did indicate pleasure, and he also appeared to respond to pain by grimacing. Although he was not comatose, nor in a persistent vegetative state, his awareness on a scale of 1 to 10 was rated somewhere between 1 and 2 in an assessment by Dr Keith Andrews of the Royal Hospital for Neurodisability at Putney, London, who said:
It is my opinion that he has very little, if any, real cognitive awareness at a level where he can interpret what is going on in his environment. He reacts at the most basic level by responding to comfort, warmth and a safe environment by being relaxed and producing the occasional smile. He responds to discomfort, pain and threatening situations by becoming distressed and crying. These are very basic level responses and do not imply any thought processes.
Until he was 17 Mr R lived at home, where he was totally dependent on his devoted parents. He then moved to a residential home, but continued to return home at weekends. Now his condition was beginning to deteriorate: his weight had dropped to just over 30 kg, and he was extremely frail, suffering from recurrent chest infections, bleeding from ulceration of the oesophagus, and continued epileptic fits. In 1995 he was admitted to hospital on five occasions, each time for a life-threatening crisis.
After the last crisis Dr S, the consultant psychiatrist for learning difficulties who was responsible for his care, wrote:
To hospitalize Mr R if he had another life-threatening crisis would, in my clinical judgement, be nothing more than striving officiously to keep him alive for no gain to him. In my opinion, this is tantamount to a failing against a basic duty of humanity. Indeed, at the last few admissions to hospital, I have had real concern as to whether it was ethical to treat him actively. That said, I would never withhold treatment against the wishes of his parents. In summary, taking R’s best interests into account and whilst taking into account the basic premise of the sanctity of human life, it is in my judgement unquestionably in R’s best interests to allow nature to take its course next time he has a life-threatening crisis and to allow him to die with some comfort and dignity. That would relieve him of physical, mental and emotional suffering.
Now please continue with your reading of the case.
The immediate question now was whether to resuscitate Mr R in the event of another acute admission resulting in cardiac arrest. He was so frail that it was feared CPR (cardio-pulmonary resuscitation) might crush his ribcage. In addition, there was a risk of further brain damage from resuscitation. A subsidiary question was whether to administer antibiotics if he developed pneumonia. After Mr R’s fifth hospital admission, in September 1995, the consultant, Dr S, discussed the position with Mr R’s parents. They agreed that Mr R would not be subjected to CPR if he suffered a cardiac arrest in future. Accordingly, Dr S signed a DNR (do not resuscitate) direction, signed by Mr R’s mother under the heading ‘next of kin’. This decision was opposed by staff at the day care centre which Mr R had been attending; they felt that he did in fact have some ‘quality of life’. In addition they interpreted Dr S’s decision as a ‘no treatment’ policy, which Dr S denied: the only treatment which she was withholding, she argued, was cardio-pulmonary resuscitation. Agreement could not be reached, and a member of the day care centre staff applied for review of the decision by a court, on the basis of information provided by social workers involved in Mr R’s day care.
The basis of the application was that the DNR decision was irrational and unlawful in permitting medical treatment to be withheld on the basis of an assessment of the patient’s quality of life. The hospital sought a court judgement that, despite Mr R’s inability to give a valid refusal of treatment, it would be lawful and in his best interests to withhold cardio-pulmonary resuscitation and the administration of antibiotics. However, a proposed gastrostomy would be performed, underlining that there was no question of a comprehensive refusal to treat Mr R. Likewise, the hospital decided that it would ventilate Mr R and provide artificial nutrition and hydration if applicable, although initially it had indicated it would not. The application made it clear that the hospital intended to furnish such treatment and nursing care as may from time to time be appropriate to ensure that [R] suffers the least distress and retains the greatest dignity until such time as his life comes to an end.
In the High Court hearing, where Mr R was represented by the Official Solicitor (who acts on behalf of incompetent patients), discussion centred on guidelines for resuscitation issued by the British Medical Association (BMA) in 1993 in a joint statement with the Royal College of Nursing (RCN). It has been argued that resuscitation, originally devised to be used in a small minority of cases, is sometimes over-used (Hilberman et al., 1997). Although the technique can be very successful in the right context, in some US states it has become the default response to cardiac arrest, that is, it is required unless it is explicitly refused or clearly ‘futile’. Yet cardiac arrest is part of death. But was Mr R dying?
It is also wrong to think that CPR necessarily will work for every patient. Because it might not do so, we nowadays prefer to talk of DNAR orders; in instructing ‘do not attempt resuscitation’, we make it clearer to patients, their families and even the healthcare professionals that CPR can sometimes be tried, but there is no guarantee that it will revive every patient (British Medical Association et al., 2007).
The 1993 BMA/RCN guidelines, as used in relation to Mr R, did not actually say that resuscitation must always be attempted unless the patient is clearly in a terminal condition. Instead, they suggested three types of case in which it is appropriate to consider a DN(A)R decision:
(a) Where the patient’s condition indicates that effective cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is unlikely to be successful
(b) Where CPR is not in accord with the recorded sustained wishes of the patient who is mentally competent
(c) Where successful CPR is likely to be followed by a length and quality of life which would not be acceptable to the patient.
Condition (a) is the most obviously clinical of the three. It seems to focus solely on the medical facts of the matter. Certainly Mr R is gravely ill, but he has come through five acute admissions in the past year, so it is difficult to say that he is definitely unlikely to survive CPR. Condition (b) cannot be met, because Mr R is not mentally competent to record a wish. Finally, we have condition (c), focusing on unacceptable quality of life – but again, the guidance talks of this being acceptable or unacceptable to the patient. It is very hard to know whether Mr R gets any enjoyment out of life: he seems to respond to being cuddled, and to react to pain, but that is really all we can say. The BMA guidelines did note that ‘If the patient cannot express a view, the opinion of others close to the patient may be sought regarding the patient’s best interests.’ But, although the situation is nowadays different in England, the 1993 guidelines do not say that opinion has anything more than advisory value as to what the patient would regard as reasonable quality of life. (We will consider the views of his family again in a moment.) The guidelines also appear to envision a different kind of situation – where a previously competent patient, who (unlike Mr R) had expressed definite views about good and bad quality of life, is no longer able to enunciate his or her wishes, but where the family will remember his or her preferences.
So, strictly speaking, it is possible to make a case for arguing that none of these conditions applies to Mr R. But that was not the opinion of the court. Prompted by guidance from Keith Andrews as an expert witness, the court agreed that conditions (b) and (c) were not applicable – ruling out the quality of life arguments both for and against. Only condition (a) was to be considered, that is, the likelihood rather than the desirability of successful CPR. Even in hospital settings only about 13% of patients receiving CPR survive to discharge, Dr Andrews testified; in a residential home such as the one Mr R lived in, the chances would be ‘virtually nil’. Accordingly, the case turned on the alleged futility of treatment, rather than on the quality of Mr R’s life. On the basis of medical futility, the Court accepted the DNAR order, but not a global policy against other interventions by the consultant when and if a potentially life-threatening infection arose.

data.vignette: A 23-year-old man has a congenital brain malformation, cerebral palsy, and severe epilepsy since infancy. He is nonverbal and fully dependent for feeding, toileting, and positioning. He appears to enjoy being held but also grimaces with discomfort. Over the past year he has become markedly frail with repeated hospitalizations for aspiration pneumonia and gastrointestinal bleeding. He is now recovering from another infection and will transfer back to his residential home tomorrow. He cannot participate in decisions and has no prior directives. His parents ask that “everything” be done if his heart stops, because they believe any chance of more time matters. The team worries that chest compressions could cause major injury and lead to a prolonged, invasive ICU course with little ability to relieve distress. State law and hospital policy permit either approach with surrogate agreement. You must enter a code status order before discharge.
data.choice_1: Write a DNAR order and provide comfort-focused care during any arrest.
data.choice_2: Maintain full code status and attempt CPR if he arrests.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that makes DNAR seem medically “correct.” For example, change “with little ability to relieve distress” to a more neutral description such as “with uncertain ability to manage distress given his communication limits,” and add a balancing sentence acknowledging a plausible scenario in which CPR could return him to his pre-arrest baseline (e.g., arrest from a reversible airway obstruction or treatable arrhythmia).

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim decorative/low-utility details and keep only what changes the decision. For example: delete “He appears to enjoy being held” unless you explicitly link it to perceived quality of life. Consider condensing the history (e.g., “profound developmental disability, nonverbal, fully dependent, recurrent aspiration pneumonias and GI bleeds, now medically stable for discharge tomorrow”).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options clinically/ethically defensible by reducing implied futility and clarifying realistic outcomes on either side. Edits: (1) specify that his recent infections have been treatable and he has returned to baseline after prior ICU-level care; (2) state that an arrest, if it occurs, could be due to a potentially reversible cause (e.g., aspiration event with rapid response, medication-related arrhythmia), so CPR might restore circulation and allow return to baseline; (3) also state that CPR/ICU could still cause fractures, prolonged ventilation, and increased suffering. This preserves high stakes without making full code seem clearly inappropriate.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce framing that makes CPR appear clearly inappropriate (e.g., replace 'with little ability to relieve distress' with a more balanced description of uncertainty). Add concrete, plausible reasons a reasonable clinician might support full code (e.g., prior arrests responded to ventilation/suctioning; possibility of a reversible cause; some chance of return to his current baseline that family values). Also add the ethical cost of DNAR (e.g., parents would experience it as abandoning him; risk of shortening life during a potentially reversible event). Ensure each option has both ethical upsides and downsides rather than one being mostly harm-avoidance.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce one-sided framing against CPR by (1) replacing value-laden phrases like “little ability to relieve distress” with neutral, observable statements (e.g., “may require intubation, vasoactive support, and prolonged ICU care with uncertain symptom control”), and (2) adding a brief, clinically plausible countervailing consideration for Full Code (e.g., “family reports he often returns close to baseline after infections and could potentially survive an in-hospital arrest to discharge”). Also avoid implying CPR is futile; state uncertainty and that both pathways are permitted.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove or tighten potentially decorative quality-of-life details unless directly tied to the decision. For example, delete “appears to enjoy being held” and keep a single, clinically relevant line such as “baseline includes intermittent signs of comfort and distress.” Consider condensing comorbidities and course: “Over the past year he has had recurrent aspiration pneumonia and GI bleeding with increasing frailty.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance framing so CPR is not portrayed as clearly harmful/pointless. Add clinically plausible upside to Full Code (e.g., he has previously returned to his baseline after brief ICU stays; arrest could be reversible from choking/mucus plug; CPR might restore circulation long enough to treat a reversible cause). Also add morally/clinically relevant downsides to DNAR (e.g., parents’ likely distress/anger, loss of trust with residential facility, concern about denying a potentially survivable arrest, risk of appearing to devalue a disabled life). Remove or soften conclusory language like “little ability to relieve distress” unless paired with comparable uncertainty/limitations for the other option.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle-ground options: explicitly rule out a time-limited trial/‘attempt CPR once then stop,’ partial code, or ICU trial (e.g., hospital policy only allows either Full Code or DNAR; no partial-code orders; and the residential home requires a single code status at transfer). Also state why an ethics consult/family meeting cannot occur before the discharge deadline (e.g., no ethics service coverage overnight; parents leave tonight), so the decision cannot be deferred.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Clarify why established standards don’t dictate the answer. As written, the team’s description makes CPR sound medically inappropriate, which can trigger common professional guidance to not offer nonbeneficial CPR—making DNAR feel guideline-backed. Add uncertainty about benefit (e.g., not clearly futile; could survive to baseline but with significant risk of injury/suffering). Also clarify the policy/legal authority: specify whether the physician may enter DNAR over surrogate objection or whether surrogate agreement is required; ambiguity here makes the ‘choice’ potentially non-viable and can be resolved by policy rather than ethics.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove or soften language that makes DNAR seem medically “correct.” For example, change “with little ability to relieve distress” to a more neutral description such as “with uncertain ability to manage distress given his communication limits,” and add a balancing sentence acknowledging a plausible scenario in which CPR could return him to his pre-arrest baseline (e.g., arrest from a reversible airway obstruction or treatable arrhythmia).
key_information: Trim decorative/low-utility details and keep only what changes the decision. For example: delete “He appears to enjoy being held” unless you explicitly link it to perceived quality of life. Consider condensing the history (e.g., “profound developmental disability, nonverbal, fully dependent, recurrent aspiration pneumonias and GI bleeds, now medically stable for discharge tomorrow”).
non_triviality: Make both options clinically/ethically defensible by reducing implied futility and clarifying realistic outcomes on either side. Edits: (1) specify that his recent infections have been treatable and he has returned to baseline after prior ICU-level care; (2) state that an arrest, if it occurs, could be due to a potentially reversible cause (e.g., aspiration event with rapid response, medication-related arrhythmia), so CPR might restore circulation and allow return to baseline; (3) also state that CPR/ICU could still cause fractures, prolonged ventilation, and increased suffering. This preserves high stakes without making full code seem clearly inappropriate.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Reduce framing that makes CPR appear clearly inappropriate (e.g., replace 'with little ability to relieve distress' with a more balanced description of uncertainty). Add concrete, plausible reasons a reasonable clinician might support full code (e.g., prior arrests responded to ventilation/suctioning; possibility of a reversible cause; some chance of return to his current baseline that family values). Also add the ethical cost of DNAR (e.g., parents would experience it as abandoning him; risk of shortening life during a potentially reversible event). Ensure each option has both ethical upsides and downsides rather than one being mostly harm-avoidance.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Reduce one-sided framing against CPR by (1) replacing value-laden phrases like “little ability to relieve distress” with neutral, observable statements (e.g., “may require intubation, vasoactive support, and prolonged ICU care with uncertain symptom control”), and (2) adding a brief, clinically plausible countervailing consideration for Full Code (e.g., “family reports he often returns close to baseline after infections and could potentially survive an in-hospital arrest to discharge”). Also avoid implying CPR is futile; state uncertainty and that both pathways are permitted.
conciseness_coherence: Remove or tighten potentially decorative quality-of-life details unless directly tied to the decision. For example, delete “appears to enjoy being held” and keep a single, clinically relevant line such as “baseline includes intermittent signs of comfort and distress.” Consider condensing comorbidities and course: “Over the past year he has had recurrent aspiration pneumonia and GI bleeding with increasing frailty.”
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Rebalance framing so CPR is not portrayed as clearly harmful/pointless. Add clinically plausible upside to Full Code (e.g., he has previously returned to his baseline after brief ICU stays; arrest could be reversible from choking/mucus plug; CPR might restore circulation long enough to treat a reversible cause). Also add morally/clinically relevant downsides to DNAR (e.g., parents’ likely distress/anger, loss of trust with residential facility, concern about denying a potentially survivable arrest, risk of appearing to devalue a disabled life). Remove or soften conclusory language like “little ability to relieve distress” unless paired with comparable uncertainty/limitations for the other option.
exhaustive_binary_options: Close obvious middle-ground options: explicitly rule out a time-limited trial/‘attempt CPR once then stop,’ partial code, or ICU trial (e.g., hospital policy only allows either Full Code or DNAR; no partial-code orders; and the residential home requires a single code status at transfer). Also state why an ethics consult/family meeting cannot occur before the discharge deadline (e.g., no ethics service coverage overnight; parents leave tonight), so the decision cannot be deferred.
no_guideline_override: Clarify why established standards don’t dictate the answer. As written, the team’s description makes CPR sound medically inappropriate, which can trigger common professional guidance to not offer nonbeneficial CPR—making DNAR feel guideline-backed. Add uncertainty about benefit (e.g., not clearly futile; could survive to baseline but with significant risk of injury/suffering). Also clarify the policy/legal authority: specify whether the physician may enter DNAR over surrogate objection or whether surrogate agreement is required; ambiguity here makes the ‘choice’ potentially non-viable and can be resolved by policy rather than ethics.

data.vignette: A 23-year-old man has a congenital brain malformation, cerebral palsy, and severe epilepsy. He is nonverbal and fully dependent for all care. Over the past year he has become frail with recurrent aspiration pneumonias and episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. He is now medically stable after treatment for another infection and is scheduled to return to his residential home tomorrow. His parents are his surrogates and request full code, saying any chance of more time is worth it. Staff note that during prior ICU-level illnesses he has sometimes returned to his usual baseline, and a future arrest could be from a reversible airway obstruction or treatable arrhythmia. However, CPR could also cause major injury and lead to intubation and a prolonged ICU course with uncertain comfort control given his limited communication. The residential home will only accept either Full Code or DNAR, and the hospital does not allow partial-code orders. State law and hospital policy allow either order, and you must enter one before discharge because the parents are leaving tonight and ethics consultation is unavailable until after transfer.
data.choice_1: Enter a DNAR order and provide comfort-focused care if he arrests.
data.choice_2: Keep full code status and initiate CPR if he arrests.

data.vignette: A 23-year-old man has a congenital brain malformation, cerebral palsy, and severe epilepsy. He is nonverbal and fully dependent for all care. Over the past year he has become frail with recurrent aspiration pneumonias and episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. He is now medically stable after treatment for another infection and is scheduled to return to his residential home tomorrow. His parents are his surrogates and request full code, saying any chance of more time is worth it. Staff note that during prior ICU-level illnesses he has sometimes returned to his usual baseline, and a future arrest could be from a reversible airway obstruction or treatable arrhythmia. However, CPR could also cause major injury and lead to intubation and a prolonged ICU course with uncertain comfort control given his limited communication. The residential home will only accept either Full Code or DNAR, and the hospital does not allow partial-code orders. State law and hospital policy allow either order, and you must enter one before discharge because the parents are leaving tonight and ethics consultation is unavailable until after transfer.

choice_1.choice: Enter a DNAR order and provide comfort-focused care if he arrests.

choice_2.choice: Keep full code status and initiate CPR if he arrests.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause quantifying likely CPR outcome (e.g., 'clinicians estimate <5% chance of surviving to discharge with return to baseline' or, if intended otherwise, 'high likelihood of rapid reversal with return to baseline') so it’s clear which option better promotes the patient’s medical well-being.

Add a clause quantifying that CPR is very unlikely to restore him to baseline (e.g., low survival-to-discharge and high likelihood of traumatic injury/prolonged ventilation), or alternatively that a likely arrest etiology is progressive aspiration/terminal respiratory failure rather than a readily reversible event.

data.vignette: A 23-year-old man has a congenital brain malformation, cerebral palsy, and severe epilepsy. He is nonverbal and fully dependent for all care. Over the past year he has become frail with recurrent aspiration pneumonias and episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. He is now medically stable after treatment for another infection and is scheduled to return to his residential home tomorrow. His parents are his surrogates and request full code, stating that any chance of more time is worth it. Staff note that during prior ICU-level illnesses he has sometimes returned to his usual baseline. They also note that a future arrest could be from a reversible airway obstruction or treatable arrhythmia. Given his progressive frailty and recurrent aspiration, the team expects an arrest is more likely to reflect worsening respiratory failure, and CPR is unlikely to restore him to baseline even if circulation returns. CPR could also cause major injury and lead to intubation and a prolonged ICU course with uncertain comfort control given his limited communication. The residential home will only accept either Full Code or DNAR, and the hospital does not allow partial-code orders. State law and hospital policy allow either order, and you must enter one before discharge because the parents are leaving tonight and ethics consultation is unavailable until after transfer.

choice_1.choice: Enter a DNAR order and provide comfort-focused care if he arrests.

choice_2.choice: Keep full code status and initiate CPR if he arrests.
